intro: Pseudognaphalium mendocinum, commonly known as the Mendocino goldenweed, is a flowering plant native to California. It belongs to the sunflower family (Asteraceae) and is characterized by its yellow composite flowers and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and slopes. It produces small, oval-shaped seeds that are dispersed by the wind. Pseudognaphalium mendocinum is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions.
